Award.AwardTitle: Real-Time Indoor and Outdoor Simultaneous Localization and Mapping

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Location-based service has been ranked as #1 in top 10 technology trends by Time magazine, with potential applications in the area of location-based advertising, recommendation, navigation, asset recovery, gaming, etc. Lots of companies are investigating and improving the location-based services. For example, Google Map is working on adding Google Store Views. However, most of the existing indoor and outdoor maps are relatively static. In reality, the indoor and outdoor environments may dynamically change over time. Therefore, there is a pressing need for novel technologies and systems to improve simultaneous localization, mapping, and navigation in modern cities (both outdoor and indoor). Moreover, in many applications, such as disaster recovery, rescuers have to cooperate with other team members to perform their tasks. Therefore, it is highly desirable that rescuers can accurately know the relative positions of their peers in real-time.

This project introduces a holistic approach for providing real-time light-weight and accurate relative positioning techniques to detect peers in both indoor and outdoor environment. The outcome of this research will constitute a significant advance in the development of theoretical foundations and practical algorithms for simultaneous localization and mapping. The broader impact of this work will be further amplified by (i) improving curriculum development with enhanced course projects; (ii) disseminating research results through high-profile tutorials and open-source sites; (iii) raising interest in technology among K-12 students and under-represented minority groups through open houses; and (iv) supporting a talented minority PhD student to successfully accomplish the doctoral study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI’s group has provided a holistic approach for providing real-time light-weight and accurate relative positioning techniques to detect peers in both indoor and outdoor environment. The outcome of this research constitutes a significant advance in the development of theoretical foundations and practical algorithms for simultaneous localization and mapping. The PI’s group has also applied the design principles and general guidelines of the localization and mapping concept in applications such as smart clinics or hospitals and homes of the elderly or disabled individuals. The PI’s group has successfully published the research results at premier conferences and in journals including IEEE International Conference on Network Protocols (ICNP), IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM), ACM Transaction on Sensor Networks, and IEEE Transaction on Mobile Computing.

 

Besides the research accomplishment, the PI has significantly enhanced a graduate level course CMSC 691 Cyber Physical Systems and incorporated the research findings in his course such as CMSC 691 Smart City and Big Data. The developed course materials have been shared within UMBC, and among other universities. The PI has also supervised multiple projects that contain 2 graduate (including one PhD dissertation) and 3 undergraduate students (one of them is a minority student). Supported by the Research Experience for Undergraduates Supplements, one of the undergraduate students (Nikola Slavov) has coauthored a top conference paper (i.e., IEEE International Conference on Communications).

 

The PI has also organized one special issue to disseminate the results to communities of interest and facilitate the discussion of latest technologies in the specific communities. This special issue is “Special Issue on Collaborative Computing and Crowd Intelligence", International Journal of Cooper- ative Information Systems (IJCIS), Volume No.29, Issue No. 01n02, 2020.
